alert.note: Alert for Boulder And Jefferson Counties Below 6000 Feet, West Broomfield County; Central and East Adams and Arapahoe Counties; Elbert, Central and East Douglas Counties Above 6000 Feet; Jefferson and West Douglas Counties Above 6000 Feet, Gilpin, Clear Creek, Northeast Park Counties Below 9000 Feet; Larimer and Boulder Counties Between 6000 and 9000 Feet; North Douglas County Below 6000 Feet, Denver, West Adams and Arapahoe Counties, East Broomfield County; North and Northeast Elbert County Below 6000 Feet, North Lincoln County (Colorado) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 01 at 8:59PM MST until January 02 at 8:00PM MST by NWS Boulder
info.description: ...SNOW CONTINUES IN THE MOUNTAINS WITH SNOW AND FREEZING DRIZZLE DEVELOPING OVER THE PLAINS TONIGHT... .A storm system over the Desert Southwest will track to the Four Corners area late tonight. On Monday, it will move across Colorado and then push into the Central Plains by Monday night. This track will support development of widespread snow, as well as some freezing drizzle across the Front Range and plains. In the mountains, scattered snow showers are expected this evening. Snow will redevelop overnight and continue through Monday and Monday evening before tapering off Monday night. Hazardous and slow travel conditions can be expected during this period. Across the foothills, I-25 Corridor, and adjacent plains, areas of snow and freezing drizzle will develop tonight. Snow shifts north of the area late tonight. Behind that, areas of freezing drizzle will be possible, leading to icy road conditions. Precipitation will trend to almost all snow by mid to late afternoon Monday, and there may be an increase in snowfall rates as well especially on the northeastern plains into Monday evening. Travelers across the foothills and plains will encounter hazardous travel conditions starting tonight and continuing through Monday and Monday evening. ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM MST MONDAY... * WHAT...Snow and freezing drizzle. Additional snow accumulations up to 4 inches and ice accumulations up to one tenth of an inch. * WHERE...Front Range Foothills, Denver metro area, Palmer Divide, and parts of the eastern plains. * WHEN...Until 8 PM MST Monday. * IMPACTS...Roads will likely become slick and hazardous. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning and evening commutes.
info.instruction: Slow down and use caution while traveling. The latest road conditions for Colorado can be obtained by calling 5 1 1 or by going to www.cotrip.org. Roads will be slick resulting in slow and hazardous travel. Allow extra time to reach your destination.
